channel.title: NYT > Business > Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Car Companies Are Paying Tariffs So You Don’t Have To
item.description: But automakers can’t absorb the cost forever and will soon begin to raise new car prices, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing

item.title: Stephen Miran, Trump’s Temporary Pick at the Fed, Could Have a Lasting Effect
item.description: Stephen I. Miran may spend only a few months on the central bank’s board of governors, but in that time he can influence the discussions around interest rates and who will become the institution’s next leader.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith

item.title: Trump Names EJ Antoni New BLS Commissioner
item.description: President Trump fired the Bureau of Labor Statistics chief earlier this month after a downbeat jobs report. The move has raised concerns about the credibility of economic data going forward.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm, Ben Casselman and Lydia DePillis

item.title: Trump Extends China Tariff Truce by Three Months
item.description: President Trump’s order continues a reprieve from the threat of escalating tariffs and export controls, which rocked the global economy earlier this year.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport

item.title: Small Businesses Brace for the Punishing Side Effects of Trump’s Tariffs
item.description: Large firms with big bank balances, workers already in jobs and households near the top of the income ladder will have an easier time navigating the economic waves.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen

item.title: What Lobsters and Chickens Reveal About Europe’s Trade Strategy
item.description: The European Union struck a trade deal that protected political priorities, like chicken and beef standards, while allowing headline-grabbing concessions. Consider lobsters.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek

item.title: Trump Is Removing Billy Long as the I.R.S. Head 2 Months After He Was Confirmed
item.description: Billy Long, a former Republican congressman, will no longer serve as the tax agency’s head. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent will oversee the agency as acting commissioner.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren, Alan Rappeport and Maggie Haberman

item.title: New Tariff on ‘Transshipped’ Goods Mystifies Importers
item.description: The Trump administration levied a hefty tariff on goods that are moved through other countries, but it has not yet fully explained its plans.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis

item.title: Staggering U.S. Tariffs Begin as Trump Widens Trade War
item.description: The duties, which the president announced last week, took effect for about 90 countries just after midnight.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm

item.title: Stocks End Mixed, as Investors Take Steeper Tariffs in Stride
item.description: The S&P 500 ended the day 0.1 percent lower, a muted move compared to the upheaval when tariffs were first announced in early April.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison

item.title: Some safe-haven assets have soared against the U.S. dollar.
item.dc:creator: Christine Zhang

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm and River Akira Davis

item.title: Swiss Businesses Fear Trump’s 39% Tariff Will Create ‘Worst-Case Scenario’
item.description: Goods shipped from the country face a 39 percent tariff in the U.S., which companies warn will have dire consequences if President Trump cannot be quickly dissuaded.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Could Raise Prices on Many Consumer Goods
item.description: The tariffs are driving up prices on everyday goods as businesses warn they can no longer absorb costs, leaving consumers to foot the bill.
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Rhone

item.title: Effect of U.S. Tariffs on British Companies Is ‘Milder Than Feared,’ Central Bank Says
item.description: Britain’s economy is driven by domestic factors more than global ones right now, the governor of the Bank of England said on Thursday, when the central bank cut interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson

item.title: Southeast Asia Looks for Clarity From U.S. on ‘Rules of Origin’
item.description: Thailand, Vietnam and other countries in the region face much higher tariffs on exports with Chinese-made components. But questions remain on how the U.S. defines a locally made product.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee

item.title: Overturning the global trade system, Trump puts his ideas to the test.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: China’s Exports Surged in July as Companies Raced to Beat Trump Tariffs
item.description: China is shipping more goods to Southeast Asia and other regions that often re-export them to the United States. China still sells three times as much to the United States as it buys.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher

item.title: Trump to Double India’s Tariff to 50% Over Russian Oil Purchases
item.description: Tariffs on Indian exports to the United States will surge to 50 percent by late August, as part of an effort by President Trump to pressure Russia into resolving its war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm

item.title: Why the B.L.S. Regularly Revises Jobs Data
item.description: President Trump fired the head of the Bureau of Labor Statistics last week and described a jobs report that included a big downward revision as “rigged.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman, Keith Collins and Christine Zhang
